an3.40:1.1: “There are, mendicants, these three things to put in charge.
an3.40:1.3: Putting oneself, the world, or the teaching in charge.
an3.40:1.4: And what, mendicants, is putting oneself in charge?
an3.40:1.5: It’s when a mendicant has gone to a wilderness, or to the root of a tree, or to an empty hut, and reflects like this:
an3.40:1.6: ‘I didn’t go forth from the lay life to homelessness for the sake of a robe,
an3.40:1.7: almsfood, lodgings, or rebirth in this or that state.
an3.40:1.8: But I was swamped by rebirth, old age, and death; by sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress. I was swamped by suffering, mired in suffering.
an3.40:1.9: And I thought, “Hopefully I can make an end to this entire mass of suffering.”
an3.40:1.10: But it would not be appropriate for me to seek sensual pleasures like those I abandoned when I went forth, or even worse.’
an3.40:1.12: ‘My energy shall be roused up and unflagging, mindfulness shall be established and lucid, my body shall be tranquil and undisturbed, and my mind shall be immersed in samādhi.’
an3.40:1.13: Putting themselves in charge, they give up the unskillful and develop the skillful, they give up the blameworthy and develop the blameless, and they keep themselves pure.
an3.40:1.14: This is called putting oneself in charge.
an3.40:2.1: And what, mendicants, is putting the world in charge?
an3.40:2.2: It’s when a mendicant has gone to a wilderness, or to the root of a tree, or to an empty hut, and reflects like this:
an3.40:2.3: ‘I didn’t go forth from the lay life to homelessness for the sake of a robe,
an3.40:2.4: almsfood, lodgings, or rebirth in this or that state.
an3.40:2.5: But I was swamped by rebirth, old age, and death, by sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress. I was swamped by suffering, mired in suffering.
an3.40:2.6: And I thought, “Hopefully I can make an end to this entire mass of suffering.”
an3.40:2.7: And now, since I’ve now gone forth, I might have sensual, malicious, or cruel thoughts. But the population of the world is large,
an3.40:2.8: and there are ascetics and brahmins who have psychic power—they’re clairvoyant, and can read the minds of others.
an3.40:2.9: They see far without being seen, even by those close; and they understand the minds of others.
an3.40:2.11: “Look at this gentleman; he’s gone forth out of faith from the lay life to homelessness, but he’s living mixed up with bad, unskillful qualities.”
an3.40:2.12: And there are deities, too, who have psychic power—they’re clairvoyant, and can read the minds of others.
an3.40:2.13: They see far without being seen, even by those close; and they understand the minds of others.
an3.40:2.15: “Look at this gentleman; he’s gone forth out of faith from the lay life to homelessness, but he’s living mixed up with bad, unskillful qualities.”’
an3.40:2.17: ‘My energy shall be roused up and unflagging, mindfulness shall be established and lucid, my body shall be tranquil and undisturbed, and my mind shall be immersed in samādhi.’
an3.40:2.18: Putting the world in charge, they give up the unskillful and develop the skillful, they give up the blameworthy and develop the blameless, and they keep themselves pure.
an3.40:2.19: This is called putting the world in charge.
an3.40:3.1: And what, mendicants, is putting the teaching in charge?
an3.40:3.2: It’s when a mendicant has gone to a wilderness, or to the root of a tree, or to an empty hut, and reflects like this:
an3.40:3.3: ‘I didn’t go forth from the lay life to homelessness for the sake of a robe,
an3.40:3.4: almsfood, lodgings, or rebirth in this or that state.
an3.40:3.5: But I was swamped by rebirth, old age, and death, by sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress. I was swamped by suffering, mired in suffering.
an3.40:3.6: And I thought, “Hopefully I can make an end to this entire mass of suffering.”
an3.40:3.7: The teaching is well explained by the Buddha—apparent in the present life, immediately effective, inviting inspection, relevant, so that sensible people can know it for themselves.
an3.40:3.8: I have spiritual companions who live knowing and seeing.
an3.40:3.9: Now that I’ve gone forth in this well explained teaching and training, it would not be appropriate for me to live lazy and heedless.’
an3.40:3.11: ‘My energy shall be roused up and unflagging, mindfulness shall be established and lucid, my body shall be tranquil and undisturbed, and my mind shall be immersed in samādhi.’
an3.40:3.12: Putting the teaching in charge, they give up the unskillful and develop the skillful, they give up the blameworthy and develop the blameless, and they keep themselves pure.
an3.40:3.13: This is called putting the teaching in charge.
an3.40:3.14: These are the three things to put in charge.
an3.40:4.1: There’s no privacy in the world,
an3.40:4.2: for someone who does bad deeds.
an3.40:4.4: whether you’ve lied or told the truth.
an3.40:5.1: When you witness your good self,
an3.40:6.1: The gods and the Realized One see
an3.40:6.2: the fool who lives unjustly in the world.
an3.40:6.3: So with yourself in charge, live mindfully;
an3.40:6.4: with the world in charge, <j>be alert and practice absorption;
an3.40:6.5: with the teaching in charge, <j>live in line with that teaching:
an3.40:6.6: a sage who tries for the truth doesn’t deteriorate.
an3.40:7.2: one who strives reaches the end of rebirth.
an3.40:7.4: that sage is determined by nothing at all.”
